questions.text: The structure marked A in the image below gives rise to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The structure marked A is ventral mesentery. The falciform ligament is a derivative of the ventral mesentery.

Mesenteries are double layers of the peritoneum that enclose an organ and connect it to the body wall. They provide pathways for vessels, nerves, and lymphatics to and from the abdominal viscera.

  • Ventral mesentery: Only the foregut has a ventral mesentery. It is attached to the terminal part of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper part of the duodenum. The ventral mesentery is derived from the septum transversum. When the liver grows into the mesenchyme of the septum transversum, it divides the ventral mesentery into 2 parts:
    • Lesser omentum- extends from the lower portion of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper portion of the duodenum to the liver
    • Ligaments of the liver- all ligaments of the liver (falciform ligament, right and left triangular ligaments, and coronary ligaments), except ligamentum teres
  • Dorsal mesentery: The foregut, midgut, and hindgut have a dorsal mesentery. This connects the organs to the posterior abdominal wall. It runs from the lower end of the esophagus to the cloacal region of the hindgut. It has the following special names in different regions:
    • Dorsal mesogastrium (or greater omentum)- stomach 
    • Dorsal mesoduodenum- duodenum
    • Mesentery proper- jejunum and ileum
    • Mesoappendix- appendix
    • Transverse mesocolon- transverse colon
    • Sigmoid mesocolon- sigmoid colon
    • Gastrosplenic ligament (stomach to the spleen), lienorenal ligament (spleen to the left kidney), and gastrophrenic ligament (stomach to diaphragm) are derived from the dorsal mesentery.

Related Pearl: Peritoneal folds and their contents

The following table shows various peritoneal folds (omenta, mesenteries and ligaments) and their contents.

Peritoneal fold

a)    Hepatoduodenal ligament 

b)    Hepatogastric ligament

Short gastric and left gastro-epiploic branches of splenic artery

Gastrophrenic ligament

Gastrocolic ligament

Right gastroepiploic artery

Splenic vessels. Also contains the tail of the pancreas

Mesentery

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for the varicose vein. He now complains of sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario in a patient with sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot is suggestive of injury to the saphenous nerve. Injury to the saphenous nerve is common following varicose vein surgery.

The saphenous nerve is the longest and largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest nerve in the body. It arises from the posterior division of the femoral nerve. It then enters the adductor canal and exits it by piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius and supplies the skin over the patella. The saphenous nerve then descends along the medial border of the tibia along with the great saphenous vein (anterior to the vein) and supplies the skin on the medial side of the knee, leg, and foot up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.

During stripping of veins in varicose surgery, injury to the saphenous nerve is common as it closely travels with the great saphenous vein. Sensory loss over the medial side of the knee, leg, and foot is observed in saphenous nerve injury. 

Other options: 

Option A: Sural nerve injury causes sensory loss over the posterior and lateral aspects of the distal third of the leg and lateral side of the foot and fifth toe. It is often used as an autologous peripheral nerve graft as it is readily identified and easy to harvest.

Option B: Superficial peroneal nerve injury causes sensory loss over the lateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum of the foot. It also causes weakness of foot eversion.

Option C: Deep peroneal nerve injury causes weakness of ankle dorsiflexion and toe extension but normal eversion of the foot.

The given image shows prominent collagen fibers arranged in bundles with intervening rows of chondrocytes. This is suggestive of white fibrocartilage.

Microscopy of fibrocartilage shows the following:

  • Chondrocytes- round in shape (in tendons they are flattened and elongated)
  • Ground tissue with collagen fibers- type I collagen fibers
  • Absence of perichondrium

Fibrocartilage is found in:

  • Articular discs (temporomandibular joint and sternoclavicular joint)
  • Intervertebral discs
  • Menisci
  • Glenoid and acetabular labrum   
  • Pubic symphysis
  • Manubriosternal joint
  • The lining of the bony grooves for tendons

The image below describes the histology of different types of catilages.

Related Pearl: Types of Cartilage

Type of Cartilage Hyaline Cartilage Elastic Cartilage Fibrocartilage
Colour Bluish opalescent Yellow White
Collagen type Type 2 Type 2 Type 1 (mainly) and type 2
Perichondrium Present (except at epiphyses & articular cartilage) Present Absent
Calcification Occurs with old age No calcification Occurs only with bone repair
Cells Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Fibroblasts & chondrocytes
Fibres Thin collagen Elastic fibres Thick collagen
Examples

Arytenoids except for apices

Cricoid cartilage

Thyroid cartilage

Trachea and bronchi

Articular cartilage at ends of bones

Epiphyseal plate

Costal cartilages of ribs

Temporary skeleton in embryo

Apices of arytenoid

Epiglottis

Corniculate cartilages

Cuneiform cartilages

Eustachian tube

Pinna(Auricle)

External auditory meatus 

Articular discs e.g. of Temporomandibular joint and Sternoclavicular joint

Intervertebral discs

Menisci

Glenoid and acetabular labrum   

Pubic symphysis

questions.text: A patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation. He also complains of hemifacial pain on clenching of teeth. On examination, pupillary reaction, light reflex, and accommodation reflex are normal. Which of the following marked nerves is involved in the above scenario?
questions.solution:
The above patient presents with features suggesting an involvement of the trigeminal nerve. The structure marked 3 is the trigeminal nerve.

Other marked structures:

  • 1- Optic nerve. The normal visual field and light reflex rules out the involvement of the optic nerve.
  • 2- Oculomotor nerve. Normal accommodation and pupillary reflex rule out the involvement of the oculomotor nerve.
  • 4- Facial nerve. Absence of motor involvement of the face rule out the involvement of the facial nerve.

The trigeminal nerve leaves the anterior aspect of the pons as a small motor root and a large sensory root. The large sensory root expands to form the crescent-shaped trigeminal ganglion, which lies within a pouch of dura mater called the trigeminal or Meckel's cave. The ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular nerves arise from the anterior border of the ganglion.

Branches of the trigeminal nerve:

  • The ophthalmic nerve (V1)
    • Leaves the skull through the superior orbital fissure to enter the orbital cavity.
    • Contains only sensory fibers
      • Cornea (photophobia)
      • The skin of the forehead, scalp, eyelids, and nose
      • The mucous membrane of paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity
  • The maxillary nerve (V2)
    • Leaves the skull through the foramen rotundum.
    • Contains only sensory fibers from
      • Teeth of the upper jaw
      • The skin of the face over the maxilla
      • The mucous membrane of the nose, the maxillary sinus, and the palate
  • The mandibular nerve (V3)
    • Leaves the skull through the foramen ovale.
    • Contains both sensory and motor fibers.
    • Sensory from:
      • The skin of the cheek, over mandible, and side of the head
      • Teeth of the lower jaw and temporomandibular joint (hemifacial pain on clenching of teeth)
      • The mucous membrane of the mouth and anterior part of the tongue
    • Motor to:
      • Muscles of mastication (pterygoids, masseter, and temporalis)
      • Tensor tympani
      • Anterior belly of digastric
      • Mylohyoid

Related Pearl: Structures passing through skull foramina

Opening Transmits
Optic canal
  • Optic nerves
  • Ophthalmic arteries
Superior orbital fissure
  • Lacrimal nerve (V1)
  • Frontal nerve (V1)
  • Nasociliary nerve (V1)
  • CNs III, IV, VI
  • Superior ophthalmic vein
  • Inferior ophthalmic vein
Foramen rotundum
  • Maxillary division of CN V (V2)
Foramen ovale
  • Mandibular division of CN V (V3)
  • Accessory meningeal artery
  • Lesser petrosal nerve
  • Emissary veins
Foramen spinosum
  • Middle meningeal artery
  • Nervus spinosus
  • Middle meningeal vein
Foramen lacerum
  • Deep petrosal nerve
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • Emissary vein
Carotid canal
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Venous and sympathetic plexus around artery
Jugular foramen
  • Inferior petrosal sinus
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • CNs IX,X & XI
  • Sigmoid Sinus continuing as IJV 
  • Middle meningeal branch of occipital artery
Hypoglossal canal
  • Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)
Foramen magnum
  • Osseo-ligamentous (anterior) compartment: 
    • Apical ligament and tip of dens
    • Upper band of cruciate ligament
    • Membrana tectoria
  • Neuro-vascular (posterior) compartment:
    • Lower end of the medulla oblongata with meninges
    • Fourth part of vertebral artery surrounded by sympathetic plexus of nerves
    • Spinal roots of accessory nerves
    • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
    • Tonsil of cerebellum.
 

 

Related Pearl: Branches of mandibular nerve

The above image shows pancreatic islet cells. Islet of Langerhans makes up the endocrine part of the pancreas.

Islets are characterized by secretory cells supported by reticulin fibers, and containing numerous fenestrated capillaries. There is a delicate capsule around each islet. They are paler than the surrounding exocrine cells, as they have less rough endoplasmic reticulum.

The image given below shows the histology of the pancreas.

The islets of Langerhans contain four major and two minor cell types:

  • Four main types are β, α, δ, and PP (pancreatic polypeptide) cells:
    • α or A cells- located peripherally and secrete glucagon 
    • β or B cells- located centrally and produce insulin 
    • δ or D cells- scattered between beta cells and secrete somatostatin
    • PP cells- are present in islets and also in the exocrine pancreas. They secrete a pancreatic polypeptide, which exerts several gastrointestinal effects, such as stimulation of secretion of gastric and intestinal enzymes and inhibition of intestinal motility. 
  • Minor cell types:
    • D1 cells secrete vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), a hormone that induces glycogenolysis and hyperglycemia. It also stimulates gastrointestinal fluid secretion and causes secretory diarrhea.
    • Enterochromaffin cells synthesize serotonin and are the source of pancreatic tumors that cause carcinoid syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Lymph nodes are secondary lymphoid organs. The structure of lymph nodes consists of an outer cortex and inner medulla. The cortex contains an aggregation of B-lymphocytes (primary follicles) and quiescent secondary follicles with a pale central germinal center.

The inner medulla consists of medullary cords (lymphocytes and plasma cells) and medullary sinuses. Between the cortex and medulla, there is an ill-defined zone called the paracortex, which contains T lymphocytes.

The image given below shows the histology of the lymph node. 

Option B: Glomerulus is a rounded tuft of anastomosing capillaries. The glomerular capillary wall is the filtering membrane and consists of fenestrated endothelial cells, basement membrane, and visceral epithelial cells called podocytes, which contain foot processes.

The glomerular tuft is supported by the mesangium containing mesangial cells and a non-cellular mesangial matrix.

The image given below shows the histology of the glomerulus.

Option C: Spleen is a secondary lymphoid organ. It contains round white pulp surrounded by red pulp. The white pulp is made up of aggregations of lymphocytes that surround a small artery or arterioles. Lymphocytes surrounding the arteriole are called peri-arterial lymphatic sheath (PALS) and contain T cells. Follicles in white pulp contain B cells.

The red pulp is a modified lymphoid tissue infiltrated with all the cells of circulating blood. It is like a sponge permeated by spaces (splenic sinusoids) lined by reticular cells. The zone of red pulp immediately surrounding white pulp is the marginal zone. This zone has a rich network of sinusoids.

The image given below shows the histology of the spleen.
